result.execSummary:
The defendant Skyla Rose Schmitt was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case. One or more other charges in this case were dismissed. The dismissed charges were not proven and have no legal effect. Skyla Rose Schmitt is presumed innocent of the dismissed charges.

  • Skyla Rose Schmitt was found guilty of OWI (4th), a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(a).
  • Skyla Rose Schmitt was found guilty of Operating While Revoked (Rev due to alc/contr subst/refusal), an unclassified misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 343.44(1)(b).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: --To pay fine of $1,500 + surcharges and costs, along with $56.74 in blood testing costs incurred by the Wisconsin State Patrol [clerk's calculation of the total: $2,958 plus $56.74= $3,014.74].  The Court grants the Defendant sixty days to pay the amount in full or to establish a payment plan with the Clerk of Courts Office. Non-payment will result in 60 days in jail with Huber privileges consecutive.

--To serve 9 months in the Jefferson County Jail, with Huber privileges, consecutive to any other sentence in being; to commence forthwith. The Court authorizes transfer of the service of the jail term to another county conditional on the term being served under the same conditions as would occur in the Jefferson County Jail. There cannot be the use of electronic monitoring for service of the jail term. 

--Defendant is required to report for commencement and service of jail sentence with absolute sobriety and without non-prescribed controlled substances in his/her system.  Non-compliance will result in loss of Huber/work-release privileges without further process. 

--DNA sample provision
Consecutive to: any other sentence in being

--AODA assessment

--Jefferson County Victim Impact Panel attendance
--Ignition Interlock Device required on any vehicle driven by the Defendant for a 27 month period

--Revocation of drivers license for 27 months

--6 demerit points assessed

--To pay costs of $443. The Court grants the Defendant sixty days to pay the amount in full or to establish a payment plan with the Clerk of Courts Office. Non-payment will result in 9 days in jail with Huber privileges consecutive.

charges.descr: Operating While Revoked (Rev due to alc/contr subst/refusal)

[MK] case called at 2:20pm  
Defendant Skyla Rose Schmitt in court with Attorney Thomas J McClure.  ADA Jeffrey Shock in court for the State of Wisconsin. 
Constitutional rights are reviewed; Elements are recited; pleas of " Guilty" are entered on Counts #1, #2, #3; factual basis is stipulated; the Court accepts the pleas, finds the Defendant guilty, and orders Judgment of Conviction entered.

Thereafter the Court dismisses Count #2 by operation of law.

On Count # 1 the Court sentences Ms. Schmitt: 
--To serve 9 months in the Jefferson County Jail, with Huber privileges, consecutive to any other sentence in being; to commence forthwith. The Court authorizes transfer of the service of the jail term to another county conditional on the term being served under the same conditions as would occur in the Jefferson County Jail. There cannot be the use of electronic monitoring for service of the jail term. 
--Days credit for time already served: 1 day
--To pay fine of $1,500 + surcharges and costs, along with $56.74 in blood testing costs incurred by the Wisconsin State Patrol [clerk's calculation of the total: $2,958 plus $56.74= $3,014.74].  The Court grants the Defendant sixty days to pay the amount in full or to establish a payment plan with the Clerk of Courts Office. Non-payment will result in 60 days in jail with Huber privileges consecutive.
--DNA sample provision
--Revocation of drivers license for 27 months
--AODA assessment
--Jefferson County Victim Impact Panel attendance 
--Ignition Interlock Device required on any vehicle driven by the Defendant for a 27 month period  
--6 demerit points assessed

On Count #3 the Court sentences Ms. Schmitt: 
--To pay costs of $443. The Court grants the Defendant sixty days to pay the amount in full or to establish a payment plan with the Clerk of Courts Office. Non-payment will result in 9 days in jail with Huber privileges consecutive.
Felony firearm/voting prohibition warnings are given. 
recess 2:58pm

[ma] Case called at 11:17 AM 
Defendant Skyla Rose Schmitt in court.  Attorney Thomas J McClure in court for Skyla Rose Schmitt.  Attorney Jeffrey Shock in court for State of Wisconsin. 

Ms. Schmitt waives her right to Preliminary Hearing; the Court accepts this waiver and binds her over for Trial.

Arraignment:
--service of Information admitted, reading waived

Constitutional rights are reviewed; plea of " GUILTY " is entered on Count #1; factual basis is stipulated; the Court accepts the plea, 

Ms. Schmitt expresses some hesitancy to proceeding today. 
recess: 11:32am--reconvene: 11:39am 

Atty McClure raises that outcome of civil matter is weighing heavy on Ms. Schmitt; requests adjournment. 

The Court sets case for trial 

The Court withdraws plea entered by Ms. Schmitt.

[MK] case called at 10:17am 
Defendant Skyla Rose Schmitt appears by telephone from the Sheboygan County Jail, in custody. Attorney Thomas J McClure appears in court.  ADA Garrett Johnson appears in court for the State of Wisconsin.
Attorney McClure indicates that the Defense has no objection to Ms. Schmitt appearing by telephone today. 
Attorney McClure requests that the Defense is requesting that a projected plea and sentencing hearing be scheduled with Zoom-appearances in approximately sixty days.  
Ms. Schmitt verifies that she understands that she has the right to be present in the courtroom for sentencing, and she is agreeing to the next hearing being held with Zoom appearances.
